chapter.title: XML Authoring Resources
chapter.para: The Mobicents User Documentation Suite is authored entirely in XML. For someone starting out with XML, there are many things to consider. What is the best authoring tool to use? What elements, and structure is definitely valid in Publican? How do I create screenshots that scale correctly?
This chapter discusses a number of helpful tips that will get a new content author up to speed quickly.

section.title: XML Structure Tips
section.para: In DocBook, the content that is being documented often benefits from advanced XML tagging. There are certain additions to structure that can be useful to help the reader in quickly grasping information. The following sections are grouped into common areas that you will use regularly in XML authoring.

section.title: Lists - Bulleted and Numbered
section.para: The two most common list types in DocBook are not named according to such programs as Microsoft Word, or Open Office. You would think that for a bulleted list, you would start the list using something like <bullets> or <bulletedlist>. Likewise, for a numbered list, you might consider looking for <numlist> or <numberedlist>.
In DocBook, these types of lists are referred to according to the following nomenclature:

formalpara.title: <itemizedlist>
formalpara.para: An itemized list is used to replace a semi-colon separated list in a sentence.

formalpara.para: An <orderedlist> is just like an <itemizedlist>, except it displays the content in number order. This type of list is better suited to listing small substeps in <procedure> lists.

section.title: Procedural Steps -
section.para: When it is necessary to document a complex set of installation instructions, an <orderedlist> is usually not the best XML element to choose. It has limitation about what level of detail each <listitem> tag can contain.
The best option for large workflows, or detailed steps, is the <procedure> element.
You may not be aware, but this element is used extensively throughout this user guide to capture the steps involved in the Authoring Process.

The biggest advantage to using a <procedure> element is that it uses the <step> element. <step> elements are classed as 'top-level' elements, and can contain a much wider variety of child elements than the <listitem> element used in <itemizedlist> and <orderedlist>.

The XML form of a procedure has a number of mandatory elements. For a complete list, refer to the DocBook.org <procedure> page. Be sure to visit the pages of the child elements that the <procedure> tag supports, particularly the <step> element.
The minimum set of elements required for all procedure lists in the Mobicents UDS are described in the following example:

example.title: <procedure> Mandatory Elements
example.programlisting: <procedure> <title><procedure> Title</title> <step> <title>Step One Title</title> <para>Step one info.</para> </step> <step> <title>Step Two Title</title> <para>Step two info.</step> </procedure>

You can further enhance the <procedure> by adding in any number of supported child elements into each <step>. Each <step> can contain any number of <para> tags, and also permits <itemizedlist> and <orderedlist> tags. Be sure that the tags inserterd are compatible with the Publican Toolchain.

example.programlisting: <procedure> <title><procedure> Title</title> <step> <title>Step 1 Title</title> <para>Step one info.
